##Research Question

How are taxes and agglomeration economies related to nonprofit firm location?

##Implications for My Project
\begin{itemize} \itemsep1em

\item Differentiating between localization and urbanization economies
\pause

\item Separating new nonprofits from older nonprofits
\pause

\item Looking at market saturation by including nonlinear terms  
\end{itemize}

##Main Results

Evidence of effect from taxes
\newline
\newline
\newline

Evidence of agglomeration economies 

#Theory

##Theory
\begin{itemize} \itemsep1em
\pause
\item<2-> Nonprofits are exempt from taxes.
\item<3-> Taxes and nonprofit market share
\item<4-> Individual tax rates
\item<5-> Government provision
\item<6-> Localization economies
\item<7> Urbanization economies
\end{itemize}

#Method

##Regression
$$prob(Y_{ij}=1)=\theta+\alpha C_{ij}+\beta I_{ij} + \delta A_{ij} + \gamma X_{ij} + \varepsilon_{ij}$$ where

$i$ is a given nonprofit firm,

$j$ is a state, and

$C_{ij}$ is corporate, state, and property tax

$I_{ij}$ is individual income tax

$A_{ij}$ measures the agglomeration of existing nonprofits

$X_{ij}$ measures demand-side characteristics related to the state
